Increase in average temperatures
Description: In South Asia, it is projected that the annual average maximum temperature will increase by 1.4–1.8 °C by 2030 and 2.1–2.6 °C by 2050, and thus, heat-stressed areas in the region could increase by 12% in 2030 and 21% in 2050. The increase in temperature is projected to be higher during the Kharif season in areas with already high temperatures. Whereas, during Rabi, an increase in mean temperature (of up to 2°C) is projected for areas which are currently cooler.

Label: Increase in extreme heat (no. of hot days)
Description: Some locations within the Indo Gangetic Plains will experience an increase in days with temperatures above 45°C. Projections indicate that by 2080, a substantial number of days will incur maximum temperatures above 50°C, particularly in northern India.

Label: Increase in extreme rainfall events
Description: Extreme rainfall events are projected to be more frequent, particularly with regards to rainfall intensity. A study of rainfall events in the Indo Gangetic Plain over 1901-2010 found a significant decrease in heavy and very heavy rainfall events. However, moderate and heavy rainfall events were found to increase during the withdrawal period of the Indian summer monsoon season.

Label: Increase in drought events
Description: A study of rainfall events in the Indo Gangetic Plain over 1901-2010 found a signiﬁcant interannual and inter-decadal ﬂuctuation in rainfall frequency and magnitude.  Such changes in rainfall pattern may lead to increased drought risk.

Label: Increasingly erratic rainfall
Description: A study of rainfall events in the Indo Gangetic Plain over 1901-2010 found a signiﬁcant interannual and inter-decadal ﬂuctuation in rainfall frequency and magnitude.

Label: Emergence of new pests
Description: New breeds of insect-pests/diseases (resistant to insecticides) have appeared over the last few decades. Blast and stem borers previously only targeted long basmati rice varieties but now cause damage to short varieties too.

Label: Increase in pests
Description: Changes in temperature and precipitation patterns in South Asia are likely to increase the incidence of crop pests.

Label: Reduced crop productivity/failure
Description: Productivity of the rice-wheat agricultural system is declining.

Label: Increase in heat stress
Description: An increase in extreme hot days is resulting in heat stress in wheat, and to a lesser extent rice crops.

Label: Water scarcity
Description: Water availability is expected to decline due to increasing average temperatures and extreme hot days and the overconsumption of groundwater resources.

Label: Change in production zone suitability
Description: It is projected that almost half of the Indo-Gangetic Plain, the major food basket of the South Asian region, will become unsuitable for wheat production by 2050.

Label: Increase in crop productivity/yields
Description: In some areas, such as the mountainous regions of Nepal, wheat yields may increase.

Label: Flash floods
Description: Flooding following extreme rainfall events is a common occurrence in the Indo Gangetic Plain.

Label: Reduced produce quality
Description: Climate change impacts and other environmental factors such as polluted groundwater negatively affect grain quality.

Label: Increase in weeds
Description: Weeds are a major challenge in intensive rice-wheat farming systems.

Label: Emergence of new diseases
Description: New breeds of insect-pests/diseases (resistant to insecticides) have appeared over the last few decades. For example, sheath blight was previously only found at the borders of rice production areas but now affects the entire system.

Label: Increase in food insecurity
Description: Around 30% of the globe’s malnourished people live in South Asia and wheat and rice yields are expected to decline due to climate change.

Label: Loss of income
Description: The incomes of smallholder farmers are declining with a decrease in crop productivity.

Label: Increase in income
Description: Improved agricultural yields enhance farmers' sales and generate increased income.

Label: Increase in poverty
Description: Poverty is widespread in the rice-wheat agricultural system and the incomes of smallholder farmers are expected to decline further with a decrease in crop productivity.

Label: Increase in food prices
Description: Climate change in South Asia is expected to reduce food supplies and increase market prices. It is projected that food prices for major food crops (e.g. rice, wheat, maize and soybean) in 2050 will be 2.5 times higher than those in 2000, and 1.5 times higher for livestock products.

Label: Unsustainable land management practices
Description: Conventional tillage under wet conditions has led to the structural degradation of soil and the burning of rice residues has led to a loss of soil nutrients.

Label: Poor water use efficiency and management
Description: Approximately 35% to 55% of irrigation water is lost before reaching the fields.

Label: Poor efficiency of farming
Description: Traditional crop management practices such as conventional wet tillage in rice-wheat cropping systems entails higher production costs and leads degradation of the natural resource base, lower input-use efficiency and higher environmental footprints. The conventional rice planting method also leads to delayed sowing of the wheat crop. Wet tillage is labour, water, time, energy and carbon inefficient, deteriorates soil health and results in lower wheat yields (8%–9%), compared with direct seeding. Traditional wheat planting involves repetitive dry tillage which leads to further delays in wheat seeding (a week later than if using zero tillage planting).

Label: Inadequate natural resource management policy
Description: In general, water management policies are inadequate due to a lack of robust data on the regional water balance.

Label: Lack of access to risk insurance
Description: Farmers in South Asia typically lack access to crop insurance.

Label: Unfavourable soil conditions
Description: Poor soil health (i.e. structural, low organic matter, macro- and micro-nutrient imbalances) is prevalent in the rice-wheat cropping system largely due to conventional farming practices and monocropping. For example, puddling, a conventional rice-wheat system practice causes soil compaction; intensive tillage results in the destruction of large aggregates; and burning of rice residue destroys soil nutrient content.

Label: Declining groundwater levels
Description: Irrigated rice is a heavy water consumer,  approximately 3,000-5,000 litres of water is needed to produce 1 kg of rice. Rice–wheat cropping system consumes about 11,650 m3/ha water (7,650 m3/ha by rice). Thus, the groundwater levels in some areas are declining at an alarming rate. For example, in some parts of Pakistan and India, groundwater tables are declining by 1.0–3.5 m and 6 m/ annum, respectively.

Label: Poor water quality
Description: Excessive use of fertilisers and insecticides in the rice-wheat farming has polluted underground water.

Label: High disease prevalence
Description: Monoculture cropping with high N-fertiliser use and wet conditions due to frequent irrigation provide conditions conducive to pest and disease outbreaks.

Label: High prevalence of weeds
Description: Weeds are prevalent in intensive rice-wheat farming systems. Common weeds in flooded rice ecosystems include Echinochloa colona and Echinochloa crus-galli.

Label: Unsuitable crop varieties
Description: Farmers in the rice-wheat system of South Asia typically plant slow maturing traditional varieties and have limited access to improved stress-tolerant genotypes.

Label: High prevalence of pests
Description: Monoculture cropping with high N-fertiliser use and wet conditions due to frequent irrigation provide conditions conducive to pest and disease outbreaks.

Label: Major component of local diet
Description: Rice and wheat are the principal calorie sources for over a billion people in South Asia. For example, rice and wheat contribute 20% and 75%, respectively, to the caloric intake in Pakistan and rice forms the staple diet for >70% of the Indian population.

Label: Labour shortages
Description: In some areas, crops are poorly managed due to labour deficits.

Label: High poverty levels
Description: The Indo-Gangetic Plains of South Asia are home to low-income smallholder farmers with per capita incomes of USD 835 per household per annum (national (India) average of USD 1,256).

Label: Low access to agricultural extension services
Description: The density of institutions providing agricultural extension services is generally low in the Indo-Gangetic Plains.

Label: Limited uptake of modern technologies
Description: There is a low adoption rate of conservation agriculture practices by smallholder farmers due to unaffordability, limited access to inputs (e.g. seeds and machinery), lack of know-how to operate machinery and fixed mindsets.

Label: Lack of access to  inputs
Description: Farmers in the rice-wheat system of South Asia have limited access to inputs such as seeds and machinery.

Label: Invest in irrigation infrastructure
Description: Farmers in the rice-wheat system of South Asia use irrigation infrastructure as a means of adapting to drought and heat stress.

Label: Adopt heat tolerant varieties
Description: A suggested adaptation option to heat stress includes breeding for heat-tolerant genotypes.

Label: Adopt early maturing varieties
Description: A suggested adaptation option to heat stress includes breeding for early-maturing genotypes with improved pollen viability and accelerated grain-filling rates.

Label: Implement climate smart agriculture practices
Description: Climate-smart agriculture practices such as the use of high-yielding and stress-tolerant varieties/genotypes, adoption of improved water management technologies, direct seeded rice, laser-assisted land levelling, permanent raised beds, precision nutrient management, carbon management through residue retention/incorporation, weather forecast technologies, crop insurance, energy saving technologies like zero tillage and information and communication technologies can be used to increase crop productivity and farm profitability when faced with a changing climate.

Label: Implement conservation agriculture practices
Description: Conservation agriculture practices are recommended to improve the sustainability of the rice-wheat system, key practices to implement include: crop rotation, reduced/no tillage and mulching and crop residue retention.

Label: Capacity building on sustainable agricultural practices
Description: Capacity building of farmers through training programmes is needed to improve the adoption of sustainable land management practices. For example, regional-level government departments in India are organising awareness campaigns through demonstrations, information dissemination, school curriculum, and information and communications technology to educate farmers on the effective management of crop residues.

Label: Invest in agricultural research and development
Description: Groundwater depletion in the rice-wheat system of South Asia requires multidisciplinary research to inform water management policy.

Label: Build the capacity of agricultural extension agents
Description: Sensitisation of agriculture extension agents on conservation agriculture technologies in conjunction with the establishment of demonstration plots will enhance adoption of the practices amongst farmers.

Label: Implement integrated weed management
Description: Integrated weed management is considered the best adaptation option for controlling weeds in a sustainable way.

Label: Undertake crop rotation
Description: Crop rotation with legumes is a common means for improving soil quality through nitrogen fixation.

Label: Plant multiple crop types
Description: Alternative crop types can be used to enhance the productivity of a system by improving soil fertility, reducing pests and diseases and improving water use efficiency.

Label: Implement water conservation irrigation
Description: Water saving technologies can be used to improve the water use efficiency of rice-wheat systems such as tensiometer-based irrigation scheduling, laser land levelling, direct seeding of rice, bed planting, subsurface drip irrigation system, furrow irrigation and alternate wetting and drying for rice production. Micro-irrigation reduces water usage by limiting surface runoff and can improve irrigation efficiency by 50%, in comparison with flood irrigation.

Label: Adjust crop calendar
Description: Due to high evapotranspiration requirements, delaying the transplanting of rice is an important method for increasing crop and water productivity in the semiarid areas of the rice-wheat system.

Label: Adopt disease tolerant varieties
Description: Disease tolerant rice and wheat varieties should be adopted to improve yields.

Label: Adopt high yielding varieties
Description: Adoption of high-yielding rice and wheat varieties/genotypes is an important climate-smart agriculture adaptation option.

Label: Establish farmer organisations
Description: The establishment of farmer groups and cooperatives provides an easy access point for government extension services and other agricultural initiatives.

Label: Develop policies for building climate change resilience
Description: Strong policy support is needed for the upscaling and adoption of sustainable land management practices.

Label: Policy reform
Description: Strong policy support is needed for the upscaling and adoption of sustainable land management practices, improved groundwater management and crop diversification.

Label: Improve access to agricultural extension services
Description: Improved agricultural extension services can be used to raise farmers’ awareness of climate change adaptation strategies.

Label: Improve access to risk insurance schemes
Description: Improving farmers' access to risk insurance schemes grants them the opportunity to adopt modern technologies and practices that may have previously been perceived by the farmers as being too risky.

Label: Improve access to credit
Description: Improving rice-wheat farmers' access to credit can indirectly enhance their climate resilience by increasing access to improved inputs, modern technologies and practices.

Label: Farmers engaged in agri system
Description: South Asia’s rice and wheat cropping system provides for millions of farmers’ livelihoods and feeds over a billion people.

Label: Loss of livelihoods
Description: Declines in rice-wheat productivity will impact the livelihoods of millions of farmers.

Label: Food insecurity
Description: Rice and wheat are the principal calorie sources for over a billion people in South Asia.

Label: Increase in average temperatures
Description: In South Asia, it is projected that temperatures will increase by 1.6°C (relative to 1981–2010) in a scenario which assumes global action aligned with commitments made under the 2015 Paris Agreement. On the contrary, a scenario with no collective action, could result in increases of 2.2°C.

Label: Increase in drought events
Description: Arid areas in South Asia are already subject to severe droughts, which are projected to increase by 5-20% by 2100. For example, during the 2010-2018 period, 11.7 million people were affected by drought in Sri Lanka.

Label: Increase in extreme rainfall events
Description: Rainfall in South Asia is becoming less predictable. Flooding in summer associated with extreme rainfall events and tropical cyclones frequently affects Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and India.

Label: Decrease in average precipitation
Description: Rainfall in South Asia is becoming less predictable with some areas experiencing a decline in average precipitation. For example, in Bangladesh, total rainfall in the wet season has decreased significantly in major rice-growing areas. Projections from 17 general circulation models (GCMs) for the period 2031–2050 indicated lower rainfall (21–75%) for the harvest period and higher evapotranspiration (1–8%). In Sri Lanka, by the year 2050, rainfall is projected to decrease by 28% during the northeast monsoon season.

Label: Rising sea levels
Description: The coastal areas of Bangladesh, India and Sri Lanka are vulnerable to sea level rise.

Label: Increase in average precipitation
Description: Rainfall in South Asia is becoming less predictable, with some areas experiencing increases in average precipitation. For example, projections from 17 general circulation models (GCMs) for the period 2031–2050 indicate mean annual rainfall increases of 200–500 mm or 7–10% in Bangladesh. In Sri Lanka, rainfall is projected to increase by 48% during the southwest monsoon by 2050.

Label: Increase in tropical cyclones/hurricanes
Description: An increase in the frequency and intensity of tropical cyclones is projected for Bangladesh, India and Sri Lanka. In Bangladesh, 90% of surveyed households mentioned they had experienced a cyclone during 2008–2012. The Sri Lankan coastline is also extremely vulnerable to cyclones and storm surges, with close to 33% of the country's population residing within 1km of coastal areas. The south-eastern areas of the rice agricultural system in India (Tamil Nadu) and the southwestern parts in Kerala are less affected by tropical cyclones and flooding.

Label: Increase in extreme heat (no. of hot days)
Description: In South Asia, the annual average maximum temperature is expected to increase by 1.4–1.8 °C by 2030 and 2.1–2.6 °C by 2050.

Label: Flash floods
Description: Flash floods are sudden local flood events that are typically due to heavy rainfall. Currently, 20 million ha of rice in Asia are subject to submergence caused by flash flooding, mostly in India and Bangladesh.

Label: Increased flooding
Description: The frequency and scale of flooding in several river basins in South Asia have increased in recent years. For example, in Sri Lanka, flooding is the most frequent and costly natural hazard, causing an estimated annual loss of USD 240 million.

Label: Coastal inundation
Description: Low lying areas in Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and India are vulnerable to coastal inundation and saltwater intrusion particularly with projected changes in sea level rise and increases in tropical cyclone frequency and intensity.

Label: Increase in pests
Description: Increasing climatic variability in South Asia is projected to create favourable conditions for pests. Rising temperatures are projected to cause pest range expansion into areas of higher latitudes.

Label: Reduced crop productivity/failure
Description: Crop productivity in South Asia is adversely affected by climate change and studies indicate that the impact of changes in temperature and precipitation patterns on crop production and food security will worsen. For example, Aman rice production in Bangladesh has reduced from 57% of total rice yields in 1980-1981 to 40% in 2005-2006, and is projected to decrease further.

Label: Increase in crop productivity/yields
Description: Studies indicate the production of Boro rice, a winter crop in Bangladesh, has improved with the increase in minimum temperature.

Label: Increase in diseases
Description: An increase in crop and livestock diseases is a major indirect effect of climate change in rice production systems of South Asia.

Label: Saline intrusion
Description: Rising sea levels will contaminate surface and groundwater resources with salt in Bangladesh, India and Sri Lanka.

Label: Soil salinisation
Description: Rising sea levels will cause salinisation of coastal agricultural lands in Bangladesh, India and Sri Lanka.

Label: Increase in soil water deficit
Description: Soil water deficit is the difference between current soil water content and field capacity. Reductions in atmospheric water due to drought or reduced rainfall increase soil water deficit.

Label: Reduced soil fertility
Description: Soil fertility is the ability of soil to support plant growth by providing essential nutrients and a chemically, physically, and biologically suitable habitat.

Label: Reduced groundwater tables
Description: Changes in regional precipitation patterns, increases in average temperatures and drought events contribute to water scarcity and an increased demand for irrigation using groundwater resources, and a subsequent depletion thereof. For example, in India, the extraction of groundwater in rice cropping systems to cope with climate-induced drought has led to a rapid decline in the groundwater table, which is expected to worsen in the future. In Bangladesh, declining rainfall patterns have reduced groundwater infiltration and runoff supply to wetlands and seasonally flooded areas, reducing aquifer recharge and resulting in a decline in groundwater tables.

Label: Reduced borehole water availability
Description: Decreases in regional precipitation patterns and increases in drought events contribute to water scarcity and an increased demand for irrigation using groundwater resources, resulting in a subsequent depletion thereof.

Label: Increase in heat stress
Description: Heat-stressed areas in South Asia could increase by 12% in 2030 and 21% in 2050.

Label: Soil erosion
Description: Increasing climatic variability and extreme climate events such as drought, heavy rainfall and strong winds  accelerate the process of soil erosion.

Label: Increase in food insecurity
Description: Climate change in South Asia is expected to enhance fluctuations in crop production, food supplies, and market prices thereby aggravating food insecurity.

Label: Increase in food prices
Description: In South Asia, it is projected that without appropriate climate change adaptation measures, food prices between 2000 and 2050 will be 2.5 times higher for major food crops such as rice.

Label: Increase in women's workload
Description: A gradual decline in rice profitability in combination with increasing population pressure is likely to force male household members to find other income streams, leaving women to manage the increasing burden of farm work.

Label: Loss of income
Description: Negative climate change impacts on agricultural production reduce farmers' incomes.

Label: Increase in income
Description: Rice production in some areas will benefit from increasing temperatures, this has positive implications for farmers' income generation.

Label: Increase in poverty
Description: Climate change, with its adverse impacts on agricultural production and natural resources, is expected to increase  fluctuations in crop production, food supplies, and market prices and aggravate poverty in  South Asian countries.

Label: Unequal opportunities for women
Description: In South Asia, access to agricultural knowledge and information is limited for women in rural areas and extension and advisory services have been unsuccessful in reaching women in general.

Label: Unsustainable land management practices
Description: The rice-based cropping system is low yielding and nutrient exhaustive leading to poor soil fertility. Tillage intensive rice cropping practices have deteriorated the physical quality of soils and decreased soil organic carbon levels. Long-term wet tillage affects soil aggregation and microorganism activity, requires more water and emits substantial amounts of methane. The use of agro-chemicals has resulted in a growth in rice production but at the cost of soil health. This is exacerbated by a lack of crop diversification.

Label: Lack of coherent policy
Description: There is a need for improved understanding of linkages between policy on rice production and the wider food system.

Label: Low access to markets
Description: The livelihoods of smallholder rice farmers in remote areas of India, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh are limited by poor infrastructure, physical isolation and limited access to markets.

Label: Low access to credit
Description: Most smallholder farmers in South Asia have limited to no access to credit facilities and other inputs  thereby restricting their ability to respond to climate change. For example, in Bangladesh, less than half (45%) of rice farmers have access to credit facilities.

Label: Lack of access to risk insurance
Description: In South Asia, the agricultural insurance market is underdeveloped. Barriers to accessing insurance include a lack of awareness, a lack of legal and regulatory frameworks, a lack of financial capability of the providers, a limited range of agricultural product, a lack of technical expertise, the high cost of insurance products and low levels of affordability by farmers.

Label: Water scarce area
Description: In South Asia, temperature increases of 1.5–2 °C could severely impact the availability of water resources due to increased monsoon variability. Water scarcity in agriculture is expected to worsen, exacerbated by increasing competition with other sectors. Furthermore, an increase in groundwater extraction to meet growing food demands is leading to a depletion of groundwater tables. For example, in Bangladesh, the area under Boro rice production has grown considerably over the past 30-40 years leading to a decline in groundwater levels and an eventual scarcity of dry season irrigation water.

Label: Unsuitable crop varieties
Description: In Sri Lanka, less than half of farmers surveyed (46%) cultivated hybrid and/or modern rice varieties in addition to traditional varieties. Drought is a particularly serious constraint to rice production, yet most farmers cultivate rice varieties that are drought-susceptible.

Label: Lack of road infrastructure
Description: Smallholder rice farmers in India, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh are severely affected by climate change due to poor infrastructure, physical isolation and limited access to markets.

Label: Inadequate storage infrastructure
Description: Rice farmers in Sri Lanka and Bangladesh are unable to save rice seed due to a lack of adequate storage infrastructure.

Label: Dependent on a single crop type
Description: South Asia's population is heavily dependent on rice production. For example, rice cultivation in Bangladesh occupies 77% of all cropland and employs 65% of the country’s labour force. Rice cultivation in Sri Lanka is not just seen as an important economic activity but is culturally significant.

Label: Major component of local diet
Description: Rice is a major staple food in South Asia. In Sri Lanka, the per capita consumption of rice is 107 kg per person per year, providing 45% of total calories consumed and 40% of total protein requirements for the country's population. In Bangladesh, rice provides 63% of the caloric intake for urban consumers and 71% for rural consumers.

Label: Inadequate agri research and development
Description: Studies of the significance of climate change on major food crops in Bangladesh have been scarce.

Label: Lack of willingness to invest in sustainable agricultural practices
Small farm size
Description: Farm sizes are declining due to an increase in demographic pressure.

Label: Invest in water harvesting and storage infrastructure
Description: The construction of water harvesting and storage infrastructure allows for supplemental irrigation in times of water scarcity.

Label: Invest in storage infrastructure
Description: Investing in storage infrastructure allows farmers to save rice seed for future cultivation thereby reducing their dependency on seed availability and allowing for reduced input costs.

Label: Invest in road infrastructure
Description: Maintaining and developing road infrastructure is important for linking rice producing communities with markets.

Label: Adopt heat tolerant varieties
Description: The development and adoption of heat tolerant seed varieties will improve yields in the face of increasing average temperatures.

Label: Adopt drought tolerant varieties
Description: Planting drought-tolerant rice varieties such as Sahbhagi Dhan and Sushk Samrat can enable farmers to cope with drought, providing yield gains of between 2% and 9% in South Asia.

Label: Adopt pest tolerant varieties
Description: Planting pest resistant rice varieties will improve yields with increasing pest outbreaks.

Label: Adopt early maturing varieties
Description: South Asian farmers are cultivating short duration varieties to respond to climate change. For example, in Bangladesh, the short duration Aman (BRRI dhan57) rice variety is replacing the long duration Aman Gutiswarna variety.

Label: Adopt salinity tolerant varieties
Description: The development and adoption of salinity tolerant rice varieties will contribute to farmers' climate resilience.

Label: Plant multiple varieties
Description: In the rice-based agricultural system the mixing of seed of early rice and late maturing deep water rice is practiced to avoid crop failure in the case of flooding. The seeds are mixed in 3:1 ratio in Tamil Nadu and Kerala. In the rice agricultural system in Sri Lanka, farmers typically cultivate more than two varieties of rice.

Label: Adopt submergence tolerant varieties
Description: The development and adoption of submergence tolerant rice varieties (e.g. gene sub1 isolated from the FR13A variety) will contribute to farmers' climate resilience.

Label: Plant multiple crop types
Description: Alternative crops can be planted on the same land each year following the main rice crop. This can be done with shorter season rice varieties. The alternative crop types can be used to enhance the productivity of a system by improving soil fertility, reducing pests and diseases and improving water use efficiency. For example, planting green manure crops such as grain legumes/pulses in rice-based systems improves soil fertility and crop productivity.

Label: Implement conservation agriculture practices
Description: Conservation agriculture practices are recommended to improve the sustainability of the rice agricultural system, key practices to implement include: crop rotation, reduced/no tillage and mulching and crop residue retention. Multi-locational trials in India found that rice-based cropping systems performed better under green manure and farmyard manure applied plots than those without organic manure. Conservation agriculture is mainly adopted on large mechanised farms in India, with adoption rates much lower on smallholder farms.

Label: Implement climate smart agriculture practices
Description: Climate-smart agriculture practices such as the use of high-yielding and stress-tolerant varieties, adoption of improved water management technologies, alternate wetting and drying, direct seeded rice and carbon management through residue retention/incorporation can be used to increase crop productivity when faced with a changing climate.

Label: Diversify livelihoods
Description: Livelihood diversification such as incorporating dairy, aquaculture, horticulture and local value-added processing as well as increased off-farm income are important household strategies to escape poverty. There is potential to replace water-intensive Boro rice with more profitable vegetables such as cucumber or high-yielding potato varieties.

Label: Adopt an integrated farming system approach
Description: An integrated farming system approach aims at increasing smallholder farmers' profitability and sustainability. With the decline in farm size due to demographic pressure, it is necessary to integrate other land-based enterprises such as dairy, fish, poultry, apiary, vegetables and fruit. Deep-water rice systems offer a suitable environment for the production of fish and other aquatic organisms. Integrated rice–duck farming systems in rice paddies provide food (weeds and pests) for ducks, and the ducks fertilise the soils.

Label: Adopt disease tolerant varieties
Description: A suggested adaptation option to an increase in crop diseases includes breeding and planting of disease tolerant varieties.

Label: Invest in agricultural research and development
Description: Targeted research is needed to develop site-specific nutrient management systems in the rice-based cropping system, including more efficient use of soil ameliorants, green and animal manures, and crop residues. Effective research and extension programmes are needed to improve farmers' production practices. Researchers should work with farmers to understand their needs and reasons for non-adoption of new technologies and practices and to co-develop solutions.

Label: Establish farmer organisations
Description: Local farmer cooperatives provide an institutional mechanism for implementing and scaling up climate-smart agricultural practices and increasing rice yields.

Label: Improve networking and knowledge exchange
Description: Improve agricultural research and development by encouraging networking and knowledge sharing between research individuals and institutions and establishing effective collaborative relationships.

Label: Establish water user associations
Description: The establishment of water user associations can be an effective means for improving water use efficiency.

Label: Policy reform
Description: Achieving more productive and sustainable rice-based cropping systems requires policy coherence across agricultural industry and trade, land and water resources management, agricultural extension systems, and marketing systems for rice and related products.

Label: Improve access to credit
Description: Improving smallholder rice farmers' access to credit facilities will allow them to adopt improved practices and technology, thereby enhancing their resilience to climate change.

Label: Improve access to risk insurance schemes
Description: Improved access to insurance for rice farmers will allow them to invest in new climate-smart practices and technologies, thereby improving their yields and income opportunities.

Label: Farmers engaged in agri system
Description: Millions of farmers are engaged in rice cultivation in South Asia, many of which are smallholders with limited capacity for climate change adaptation. For example, in India, more than 80% of rice farmers belong to small and marginal groups.

Label: Food insecurity
Description: Rice is a food staple in South Asia. Climate change is expected to result in fluctuations in rice production and market prices thereby aggravating food insecurity.

Label: Loss of livelihoods
Description: Climate change is reducing rice yields and affecting the livelihoods of millions of farmers in South Asia, particularly smallholders with limited capacity for climate change adaptation. For example, in Bangladesh, more than 25% (1.8 million) of the total labour force is engaged in agricultural activities, with rice being the most important cereal crop accounting for about 16% of the total land area and contributing 7% to agricultural GDP.

Label: Increasingly erratic rainfall
Description: Erractic rainfall characterised by unpredictable onset and ceasation of rainfall,  ‘false starts’ and shorter duration of rainy seasons with intervals of extreme rain or absence of it resulting in flooding or droughts. Rainfall seasonality is relatively reliable in the system. However the volume and distribution of rainfall in time during the rainy season(s) and space is highly unpredictable, with significant risks of crop failure.

Label: Increase in drought events
Description: Extreme drought occurences are increasing and are worsening food insecurity in the regions

Label: Decrease in average precipitation
Description: Reduced or variable rainfall and increased heavy rainfall events. In Senegal Rainfall decreases range from -150 to -50 mm across much of the country; Summer rains have remained steady in Senegal over the past 20 years but are 15% below the 1920– 1969 average.

Label: Increase in average temperatures
Description: Since 1960, the average temperature has increased by 0.9°C. By 2060, average annual temperatures are projected to rise by 1.1– 3.1°C.

Label: Increase in extreme heat (no. of hot days)
Description: Increase of 27 hot days per year since 1960 in Senegal. By 2060, substantial increases in the frequency of hot days and nights are projected, with more rapid increases in the south and east of Senegal

Label: Increase in extreme rainfall events
Description: Excessive rainfall occurs causing flooding in lowland areas

Label: Increased flooding
Description: Flooding in lowland areas due to excessive rainfall. When flooding occurs, sorghum plots on heavier lowland soils with high moisture retention perform poorly, while millet will tend to produce well under these conditions on the lighter soils of slopes and plateaus

Label: Increase in diseases
Description: Increase in vector-borne diseases such as Rift Valley Fever and malaria as a result of increased precipitation  and temperature in the south of Sahel.

Label: Reduced crop productivity/failure
Description: Climate change will have an impact on crop yields. Yields of maize, millet and sorghum are projected to decline, while yields of cassava, cow peas, groundnutsand rice are projected to benefit from CO2 fertilisation. Farmers will need to adapt to these changing conditions

Label: Reduced herd size
Description: During drought, culling of weak livestock for food and cash needs

Label: Reduced fodder availability
Description: Drought causing reduced fodder and  water availability

Label: Reduced forage quality
Description: Projections into the future generally indicate widespread negative impacts on forage quality

Label: Change in production zone suitability
Description: As a result of climate change agropastoral-pastoral margin will retreat across Africa resulting in less area climatically suited for productive agropastoral practices.

Label: Water scarcity
Description: Increased temperatures causing reduce water and pasture avilability  hence causing reduction in livestock health and competition for resources and conflicts

Label: Increased incidence of bushfires
Description: Bush fire incidences occurs in pastoral systems often during. Extreme drought events are likely to worsen such practices

Label: Increase in pests
Description: Amplified effects of parasites due to lowered immunity associated with poor nutrition.

Label: Decrease in diseases
Description: Decrease in vectoral diseases e.g. tsetse fly.

Label: Increase in livestock mobility
Description: Increase in livestock mobility in search for water and forage.

Label: Competition for resources
Description: Competition with non-nomadic farmers for access to water.

Label: Increase in poverty
Description: Close to 100 million farmers, half of them extremely poor, live in the African agropastoral farming system characterized by highly variable, semi-arid climate and poor soil conditions

Label: Unsustainable natural resource use
Description: Unsustainable land and water management practices in the system  which contributes to land degradation,reduced productivity

Label: Demographic pressure on land
Description: Key trends in the system include rapid population growth and urbanization

Label: Unequal opportunities for women
Description: A major gender gap in the agropastoral system concerns customary access to land, the most basic production factor.

Label: Weak land tenure and access rights for women
Inadequate climate information services
Description: Information on weather predictions and early warning mechanisms is often inadequate  and untimely

Label: Low access to markets
Description: Both domestic and international market systems are underdeveloped in most systems. In East Africa pastoralists travel Long distance from the urban centres

Label: Lack of access to market information
Description: To reduce financial risks and purchase of inputs such as fertiliser, slash and burn is used to control weeds and a limited form of shifting cultivation are only practised in low population areas, for example Mozambique and Zambia, and also in southern Ethiopia, as justified by bush encroachment in bimodal and subtropical bioclimates

Label: Water scarce area
Description: Reduced water availability since 1960, especially around the Senegal River Basin.

Label: High prevalence of land degradation
Description: Land degradation affects 34% of the territory. Soil degradation is prominent, it is primarily caused by overgrazing and forest clearing.

Label: Unfavourable soil conditions
Description: The system is characterized by highly variable, semi-arid climate and poor soil conditions.

Label: Land fragmentation
Description: The increasing subdivision and privatization of land in East Africa particularly Kenya complicates livelihoods as it may lead to fencing, which reduces livestock access to pasture, watering points and saltlicks, and curtails mobility during drought.  In west Africa, there is increasing restriction to mobility due to expansion of crop field into grazing land. Some pastoralists go on long distance transhumance to sub-humid zone

Label: Small farm size
Description: Farm sizes are usually small and diversity is the norm in West African farming systems. Even at the level of the individual farm unit, farmers typically cultivate 10 or more crops in diverse mixtures that vary across soil type, topographical position and distance from the household compound.

Label: Limited uptake of modern technologies
Description: Low adoption of new technology is mostly related to their low profitability and perceived risks rather than available capital

Label: High poverty levels
Description: Close to 100 million farmers, half of them extremely poor, live in the African agropastoral farming syste.  Senegal for example is has 47% of the population living under the national poverty line.

Label: Unequal opportunities for women
Description: Gender inequality  is high in the system due to traditional social and religious norms.

Label: Limited uptake of modern technologies
Description: Smallholder farmers lack the capacity to process, store or distribute agricultural products.

Label: Lack of knowledge on processing/value addition
Description: Smallholder farmers lack the capacity to process, store or distribute agricultural products.Technology will play a significant role in adapting pastoral and agro-pastoral systems to climate change

Label: Predominantly small-scale subsistence farming
Description: More than 90% of Senegal's agricultural land is comprised of small-scale, family-based farms engaged in subsistence and rain-fed agriculture.

Label: Conflict prone area
Description: Tradition of violent theft of cattle (cattle rustling) and problem of armed rebellion in the Horn of Africa. Ther is also conflict occassionally along transhumance routes West Africa. In some other parts agro-pastoralist land is being lost to agricultural investors and this is likely to hinder mobility. This is likely to affect traditional migratory routes  for different seasons

Label: Unequal opportunities for women
Description: One of the challenges for the system is land resource access and tenure constraints especially for women.  Customary tenure systems continue to predominate in the system, especially in rural areas, in spite of statutoryefforts to ‘modernize’ the tenure landscape in recent decades.

Label: Lack of willingness to invest in sustainable agricultural practices
Dependent on a single crop type
Demographic pressure on land
Description: Demographic pressure on land is transforming transhumance and communal grazing to more sedentary forms of production.

Label: Implement reforestation practices
Description: Scale-up agroforestry interventions e.g. farmer-managed natural regeneration (FMNR).

Label: Invest in water harvesting and storage infrastructure
Description: Construction of small dams in Senegal to collect water for farming and animal use

Label: Diversify livelihoods
Description: Farmers adapt to uncertain climatic and environmental conditions through a range of adaptive management practices such as adoption of short cycle cultivars, the relocation of some crops and the practice of market gardening in rainy conditions alternating according to the seasons and women breeding small ruminants for sale.

Label: Promote literacy
Description: An increase in education amongst pastoralist communities, resulting in increasing opportunities for new employment and diversification, and participation in national political processes

Label: Build women's  capacity
Description: Increase women access to land resources and paid labour to enhance their benefits and enable them to access opportunities for value addition and improved production

Label: Implement fodder management
Description: Promote market-driven models to establish fodder production via such as purely rain-fed fodder production,rain-fed fodder with supplemental irrigation from harvested rainwater (e.g., sub-surface dams) andf odder production based on the groundwater irrigation for sites with groundwater table close to the surface.

Label: Implement efficient water management
Description: In southern Africa some of the strategies include reducing the plant population to reduce the water demand by crops.

Label: Diversify livestock
Description: Shift to small ruminants and camels.

Label: Adopt drought tolerant varieties
Description: Adaptation strategies such as switching to improved varieties in climate change-sensitive crops need to be considered, yet should be carefully weighed against adverse outcomes, such as a resulting decline of agro-biodiversity and loss of local crop types

Label: Plant multiple varieties
Description: Cultivar devopment targeting varieties that response to more than one threats

Label: Implement efficient water management
Description: Implement water conservation technologies alongside cultivar development e.g irrigation and water harvesting, sub, surface dams along river beds

Label: Implement agroforestry practices
Description: Integrating trees with crops serve as “nutrient pumps,” bringing nutrients that are too deep for crops. They can be used to enhance soil nitrogen, when nitrogen-fixing trees are planted. Their leaves can serve as mulch which might suppress some weed growth but would also help cool the soil.

Label: Improve climate change awareness
Description: With climate information services, farmers will be able to plan their planting and make projections about rainfall distribution patterns and temperature variations

Label: Implement conservation agriculture practices
Description: Soil organic matter is beneficial to cultivation, due to its abilities to improve soil structure and enhance water and nutrient retention. It includes practices such as no-till agriculture, offseason cover crops, use of animal manure and biochar.

Label: Capacity building on sustainable agricultural practices
Undertake crop rotation
Description: Limited form of shifting cultivation are only practised in low population areas, for example Mozambique and Zambia, and also in southern Ethiopia, as justified by bush encroachment in bimodal and subtropical bioclimates

Label: Establish farmer organisations
Description: A significant potential for poverty reduction is expected through the intensification and diversification of the agropastoral system, especially among farmers who are able to organize themselves in farmer associations.

Label: Build the capacity of agricultural extension agents
Description: Build capacity and support technical and extension services and research.

Label: Invest in agricultural research and development
Invest in agricultural research and development
Description: Incorporating in R&D approaches to build a whole system capacity and adopting an integrated approach that addresses the range of constraints farmers face along the value chain.

Label: Land tenure reform
Description: Improve land tenure and access rights in the agropastoral system.

Label: Improve access to climate information services
Description: Increased access to agricultural support services, which improves the availability and the quality of relevant climate information will further enhance awareness of climate change within of the rural community and result in better management of climate-induced risks in these vulnerable agricultural systems.asts and early warning systems.

Label: Improve access to agricultural extension services
Develop/improve early warning systems
Description: Use of intricate systems of local knowledge to predict weather or forecast a climatic event. This allows pastoralists to better plan for and manage drought (for example, agro-pastoralists in Kenya use indigenous indicators of rainfall variability to interpret meteorological forecasts)

Label: Improve access to markets
Description: Improved access to markets for tree products, cereals and animal feeds has increased commercialisation of the products and competition for resources.I Market access also enhance diversified production and community resilience.

Label: Improve access to credit
Description: The conversion of livestock resources into financial resources through uptake of saving schemes which can smooth livelihood volatility. Credit schemes may help with investment that can increase productivity or livelihood diversification

Label: Facilitate access to loans
Description: Sharing, loaning and gifting of livestock is part of pastoralists’ traditional social networks, but intensifies during and after drought. Also sharing of labour between families to act as a social safety-net

Label: Improve access to market information
Description: Develop market information systems.

Label: Improve access to risk insurance schemes
Farmers engaged in agri system
Description: More than 90% of Senegal's agricultural land is comprised of small-scale, family-based farms engaged in subsistence and rain-fed agriculture. The livestock sub-sector employs about 3 million people.

Label: Area of land used
Description: Permanent meadows and pastures for livestock rearing constitute 29% of Senegal's total harvested land area.

Label: Risk to farmers of loss of livelihoods due to Climate Change
Description: Climate change affecting the ability to sustain agro-pastoralist livelihoods in East africa region

Label: Risk to farmers of food insecurity due to Climate Change
